sen.j: 羅城門の鬼、羅生門の鬼（らしょうもんのおに）は、平安京の正門・羅城門に巣食っていたといわれる鬼。
sen.e: "Rajomon no oni" is an ogre who was said to have lived at Rajo-mon Gate, the main gate of Heiankyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

sen.j: 源頼光が酒呑童子を討伐した後、自分の屋敷で頼光四天王と藤原保昌とともに宴を催していたところ、平井（または四天王の1人・卜部季武）が、羅城門に鬼がいると言い出した。
sen.e: After putting down Shuten Doji (an leader of a group of ogres, also bandits that roamed the region around Kyoto), MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu had a feast at his residence with his four loyal retainers and FUJIWARA no Yasumasa, then Hirai (or one of the four retainers, URABE no Suetake) started to say that there was an ogre at Rajo-mon Gate.

sen.j: 四天王の1人・渡辺綱は、王地の総門に鬼が住む謂れはないと言い、確かめるために鎧兜と先祖伝来の太刀で武装して馬に乗り、従者も従えずに1人で羅城門へ向かった。
sen.e: One of the four retainers, WATANABE no Tsuna said it was irrational that there was an ogre at the main gate of the domain of the Emperor, and to determine if it was true or not, he rode a horse in full armor, with an ancestral sword and headed for Rajo-mon Gate alone, without any followers.

sen.j: 九条通に出て羅城門が正面に見えてきた頃、急に激しい風に見舞われ、馬が動かなくなった。
sen.e: When he got to Kujo-dori Street and saw Rajo-mon Gate ahead of him, strong wind stunned the horse.

sen.j: 綱が馬から降りて羅城門へ向かうと、背後から現れた鬼に兜をつかまれた。
sen.e: Tsuna dismounted the horse and made his way toward Rajo-mon Gate, then he was grabbed his "kabuto" (helmet) by an ogre came from behind.

sen.j: すかさず綱が太刀で斬りつけたが、逆に兜を奪われた。
sen.e: Soon, Tsuna struck back with the sword, but he had his kabuto taken instead.

sen.j: 綱の太刀と鬼の鉄杖が激しくぶつかり合った末、綱はついに鬼の片腕を斬り落とした。
sen.e: After Tsuna's sword and the ogre's steel stick heavily clashed, Tsuna finally slashed off an arm of the ogre.

sen.j: 鬼は「時節を待ちて、取り返すべし」と叫んで、空を覆う黒雲の彼方へ消えて行ったという。
sen.e: The ogre shouted, 'I would watch for the chance and get it back', and said to have gone in the dark clouds which covered the sky.

sen.j: 『平家物語』剣の巻にある一条戻橋の鬼の話では、綱が鬼の腕を斬り落とす場面の舞台は一条戻橋であり、この後に鬼が綱の乳母に化けて腕を奪い去るとある。
sen.e: In the tale of ogre at Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge in the chapter, named "Tsurugi (sword)" of "Heike Monogatari (The Tales of the Taira family)", the scene Tsuna slashed off an arm of the ogre was set on Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge, and after that, it is said that the ogre changed himself into Tsuna's nanny and took his arm away.

sen.j: 謡曲『羅生門』は『平家物語』で綱と鬼との戦いまでの話をもとに、舞台を一条戻橋から羅城門に変えて創作されたものとされ、その後の鬼の報復の話は謡曲では『羅生門』とは別作品の『茨木』になっている。
sen.e: Yokyoku "Rashomon"is considered to have been created by transferring the set of th escene from Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge to Rajo-mon Gate, based on the story of the battle of Tsuna and the ogre in "Heike Monogatari," and the story of the ogre's retaliation afterwards is in yokyoku "Ibaraki" which is a different story from "Rashomon".

sen.j: このことから、別々の鬼である羅城門の鬼と茨木童子がしばしば同一視される。
sen.e: This makes Rajomon no oni and Ibaraki Doji (an ogre who was Shuten Doji's follower) often being identified even though they were different ogres.
